subject: meta-phosphor: Add debug-trigger recipe
commitMessage:
meta-phosphor: Add debug-trigger recipe

debug-trigger listens for an external signal that the BMC is in some way
unresponsive. When the signal is received it triggers a crash to collect
debug data and reboots the system in the hope that it will recover.

Change-Id: Ib8ea615c2944edb0448b06c333b6e2abbea15687
Signed-off-by: Andrew Jeffery <andrew@aj.id.au>

I don't think this should be a PACKAGECONFIG.  There is already a DISTRO_FEATURE for it.  If you really think it is valuable to be able to configure the recipe for non-systemd, I would suggest copying what is done in obmc-console.bb.
How do PACKAGECONFIG and DISTRO_FEATUREs interact? My gut feeling was DISTRO_FEATURE selected the appropriate PACKAGECONFIGs
Did you look at obmc-console.bb?  I feel like this answers your question.

You're talking about

 PACKAGECONFIG ??= "udev ${@bb.utils.filter('DISTRO_FEATURES', 'systemd', d)}"

from obmc-console.bb? Or this?

 PACKAGECONFIG[systemd] = "--with-systemdsystemunitdir=${systemd_system_unitdir}, \
                           --without-systemdsystemunitdir"

The latter is entirely dependent on the build system options, and the former isn't what you've highlighted here?

Either way it's not terribly different to what I've done here, other than using the filter helper to select systemd from DISTRO_FEATURES?

>  PACKAGECONFIG ??= "udev ${@bb.utils.filter('DISTRO_FEATURES', 'systemd', d)}"

This.

> PACKAGECONFIG[systemd] = "--with-systemdsystemunitdir=${systemd_system_unitdir}, \
                           --without-systemdsystemunitdir"

You already have your own package-specific variant of this.

> Either way it's not terribly different to what I've done here, other than using the filter helper to select systemd from DISTRO_FEATURES?

Correct.  You use DISTRO_FEATURES in this case because it is already widely accepted of a OE configuration option and it thus avoids having to .bbappend a hundred recipes with modifications to PACKAGECONFIG.

Alternatively you could bypass PACKAGECONFIG and _append to EXTRA_OEMESON using a @bb.utils.contains to insert your -Dsystemd=true directly into the meson options, but PACKAGECONFIG is a more common pattern.

> >  PACKAGECONFIG ??= "udev ${@bb.utils.filter('DISTRO_FEATURES', 'systemd', d)}"
> 
> This.

Right, so it seems I was thrown off by your choice of highlighting.

Right, I'll go with PACKAGECONFIG and the filter on DISTRO_FEATURES.
This seems a little excessive.  Can we do this in a way to pass in a list of debug triggers instead of unwinding an array?  '-Dp10bmc-debug-trigger=kcs1,kcs3'.

I don't know? This sort of thinking out loud should be followed up with a PoC implementation.

If you want to improve it I'm happy to review the patch.

> I don't know? This sort of thinking out loud should be followed up with a PoC implementation.

It wasn't "thinking out loud".  It was a nice way of saying this looks pretty terrible and there are other options than "unrolling a loop".  If someone named a bunch of variables foo_0, foo_1, foo_2 it wouldn't be out of line to suggest an array.

If that is the attitude, I'd prefer we put this verbosity in a meta-openpower bbappend.

> It wasn't "thinking out loud". 

If it wasn't then I think this needed to be phrased better:

> Can we do this in a way to pass in a list of debug triggers instead of unwinding an array?

To me that reads that you're not sure and are asking the question, hence thinking out loud. Given you've stated that you weren't thinking out loud, something more direct would have helped.

Anyway, I understand arrays as a concept. I'm still learning meson, so the request for a PoC was to help me make changes there with fewer iterations of you not liking whatever it was I cooked up. The existing build system support is here: https://github.com/openbmc/debug-trigger/blob/master/meson.build

> If it wasn't then I think this needed to be phrased better:

I've gotten feedback in the past that most people tend to prefer my review comments to be less direct.  I'll try to keep yours direct.

> I'm still learning meson, so the request for a PoC was to help me make changes there with fewer iterations of you not liking whatever it was I cooked up.

That was similarly not obvious.  It came across to me more that you were blowing me off with a 'patches welcome'.  I honestly review 100-300 commits a month around here.  If I had to provide the 'fixes' for every review comment of mine I'd really get nothing else done.

Anyhow, this is a fairly common / accepted pattern in meson and I don't think requires much change to your current meson.build.

https://github.com/openbmc/debug-trigger/blob/master/meson.build#L23
https://mesonbuild.com/Build-options.html#arrays <-- also see 'array_opt' in examples at top of the page.
https://mesonbuild.com/Reference-manual.html#array-object <-- arrays can use .contains or python-like 'foo in array' syntax.

Arrays are passed to meson as a comma-separated list (like I gave in the original example) or you can optionally wrap them in a [] for "clarity".

> fewer iterations of you not liking whatever it was I cooked up

My only requirement is that there is at most one PACKAGECONFIG for the debug triggers.  I don't think we should have to add a new PACKAGECONFIG for each and every way that we can trigger the debug, and looking at your meson.build / meson_options this seems problematic to maintain there as well.  You could have a recipe-local variable for the configured debug triggers which is passed as an array_opt to meson.

This might be one possibility, based only on the fact that you're seemingly using this option to install udev rules, but you're free to name/configure these differently and/or using EXTRA_OEMESON instead of PACKAGECONFIG:

DEBUG_TRIGGERS ?= ""
PACKAGECONFIG[udev] = "-Dudev-triggers=${DEBUG_TRIGGERS}"

Any particular reason for the tabs in here? In general OpenBMC tries to avoid them.
Ugh, I'll fix that. Thanks

I was realizing that ${DEBUG_TRIGGERS} itself will contain some commas and I wonder if bitbake will for some reason interpret those commas as belonging to the PACKAGECONFIG.  Have you tested that you don’t need a [] around this here?
Oof. Adding []s wouldn't solve it unless bitbake was aware of that syntax right? The PACKAGECONFIG documentation doesn't suggest that it is.

You're right.  The code is in base.bbclass and it just does a simple Python split.

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/poky/meta/classes/base.bbclass#L452

Right now the PACKAGECONFIG values are obtained a few lines above that with a simple getVarFlags call, which happens to default to expand=False.  So, it will do the right thing even without a [].

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/poky/meta/classes/base.bbclass#L408

There is an interesting comment in the most recent Yocto documentation though: https://www.yoctoproject.org/docs/latest/ref-manual/ref-manual.html#migration-2.1-expand-parameter-to-getvar-and-getvarflag-now-mandatory  .  The 'note' here implies they're going to change the expand default to True at some point, yet the base.bbclass hasn't been updated to show their intended direction.  We could email upstream to see what the thoughts are.
I don't see an Install section in the service out at https://github.com/openbmc/debug-trigger/blob/master/systemd/system/debug-trigger%40.service. How does this service get put into the build image?

The unit is started by dynamically adding a dependency to the device unit via SYSTEMD_WANTS=, e.g:

https://github.com/openbmc/debug-trigger/blob/master/udev/rules.d/debug-trigger-kcs2.rules#L2

Documentation for this is here:

https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.device.html#SYSTEMD_WANTS=
